docs.abstract: From a penthouse on Central Park, Guo Wengui has exposed a phenomenal web of corruption in China’s ruling elite — if, that is, he’s telling the truth.
docs.snippet: From a penthouse on Central Park, Guo Wengui has exposed a phenomenal web of corruption in China’s ruling elite — if, that is, he’s telling the truth.
docs.lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday afternoon, an exiled Chinese billionaire named Guo Wengui was holding forth in his New York apartment, sipping tea while an assistant lingered quietly just outside the door, slipping in occasionally to keep Guo’s glass cup perfectly full. The tycoon’s Twitter account had been suspended again — it was the fifth or sixth time, by Guo’s count — and he blamed the Communist Party of China. “It’s not normal!” he said, about this cycle of blocking and reinstating. “But it doesn’t matter. I don’t need anyone.”

headline.main: The Mystery of the Exiled Billionaire Whistle-Blower

docs.abstract: The places we go aren’t passive; they invite us to photograph them in certain ways.
docs.snippet: The places we go aren’t passive; they invite us to photograph them in certain ways.
docs.lead_paragraph: We carry the cameras built into our phones around all the time, and the resulting flood of images says something about what people, in the aggregate, like to photograph. There are sunsets, meals, selfies, babies, dogs from dog people, cats by cat persons. There are distinctly contemporary ways of taking pictures at a party or of photographing landscapes. Originality, always hard to come by, is getting harder.

docs.abstract: Three-quarters of parents underestimated the total amount of sugar in common foods like juice, yogurt and pizza.
docs.snippet: Three-quarters of parents underestimated the total amount of sugar in common foods like juice, yogurt and pizza.
docs.lead_paragraph: More than 18 percent of elementary-school-age students in the United States are obese, and no one really knows why. The causes are numerous and tangled. But consuming too much sugar is widely accepted as an important factor. In 2015, the World Health Organization issued a recommendation: Everyone, regardless of age, should restrict his or her sugar intake to less than 10 percent of all calories consumed daily. For young children, that would mean no more than about 45 grams of sugar a day. Of course, few young children are responsible for their own diets or can be expected to capably monitor their sugar consumption. That oversight usually falls to a parent. And a recent study published in the International Journal of Obesity suggests that most of us, alas, are not adept at estimating how much sugar is in some common foodstuffs.

headline.main: Parents Aren’t Good Judges of Their Kids’ Sugar Intake

docs.abstract: The drawings, scratchings and markings left by American soldiers are small acts of rebellion on the battlefield, where there is little room for dissent.
docs.snippet: The drawings, scratchings and markings left by American soldiers are small acts of rebellion on the battlefield, where there is little room for dissent.
docs.lead_paragraph: About 5,000 years ago, someone decided to paint a battle scene between archers in a cave in Spain — perhaps one of the first instances of what we’d call “war graffiti” today. That person was probably an early grunt who had just finished griping that the chow was bad and that he’d had to march too far that day. Because as long as there has been war, there have been soldiers leaving behind their doodles, names or other markings for historians to muse on why they did so.

headline.main: The History Behind the Graffiti of War
